subject: Re: [junit] Fork each test method?
msgSnippet: Think of it this way...  MockObjects are NOT just a way of testing code, they are a tool used to design loosely coupled, well factored systems. If you can
messageBody:
Think of it this way... MockObjects are NOT just a way of testing code,
they are a tool used to design loosely coupled, well factored systems.
If you can easily mock out the whole of an encompassing system in order
to test one itty-bitty unit, you PROBABLY have done a very good job of
following the creme-de-la-creme principles of Object Oriented
Programming. I don't look at them as kludges.

The real issue may not be the test code. It may be in the design of the
production code, "may" being the operative word here since I don't
presume to pass judgment on your code base.

HTH,
=jason

On Mon, 2003-06-16 at 16:48, robert_difalco wrote:
> Is there a way to get each test method to run in it's own JVM? I am
> finding that setUp and tearDown are not enough. I have a lot of code
> that has to reset static state such as caches each time a test is
> run, code that is only needed for unit testing. If each test method
> ran in it's own JVM, my testing code would not require me to make
> changes in the code I am testing.
>
> It's not just singletons but also caches that should be initialized
> once for a JVM. And, honestly, if you think about it, each test
> method SHOULD be atomic. Mock objects seemed kind of like a kludge
> for tests not being run atomically.
>
> Thoughts?
>
> R.
